title: Kenya: Smugglers Thrive, but Kenya Millers Stuck With Sugar
text:
Zambia: Cement Prices to Drop Further 
Mr Wamang'oli blamed high prices of local sugar on cheap imports. 
Whereas retailers buy a packed kilogramme of sugar from the millers at an average of Ksh73 ($0.7), they resell it at Ksh125 ($1.3), 70 per cent more, according to the Agriculture, Fisheries and Food Authority (AFFA). 
Mumias closed indefinitely on July 13 to allow time to repair its dilapidated machinery, further creating room for more imported sugar. The company was producing 21 tonnes daily compared with its capacity of 840 tonnes daily as per July 15 statistics by AFFA, translating into 2 per cent of its capacity with no sugar left in its stocks. 
Nzoia and West Kenya are producing at 88 per cent of their capacity each. Chemelil, Sony and Muhoroni are producing at 30 per cent, 55 per cent and 45 per cent of their total capacity. Transmara, Kibos and Sukari companies are producing at 70, 75 and 58 per cent respectively. 
According to AFFA's Alfred Busolo, while firms are producing at an average of 50 per cent, there should be a shortage but this is not so. 
"Currently there is adequate sugar in the market from the EAC, Comesa and smugglers. We have discussed the issue with the Kenya Police, Kenya Revenue Authority and Kenya Bureau of Statistics to find a lasting solution," said Mr Busolo, saying it is not in the government's mandate to control the retail prices. 
AFFA is drafting stiffer penalties on counterfeits. 
"The penalties will be several times the value of the counterfeit consignment," said Mr Busolo. 
KEBS is currently sourcing a technology that will provide a secret code on the branded sugar packets that can be detected by the factory of origin. A swipe of the packet should produce the dates of packaging and the supervisor in charge on the given date. 
Kenya produces 600,000 tonnes of sugar annually, against a demand of 800,000 tonnes. The country produced 591,658 tonnes of sugar in 2014 (year ending June), a 1.4 per cent drop from a record harvest of 600,179 tonnes in 2013, blamed on low cane supply and companies' inefficiencies. 
Meanwhile, Mumias is hoping to regain the confidence of the farmers by clearing the Ksh680 million ($6.8 million) owed to the farmers. 
The firm required Ksh3 billion ($300 million) to clear its short term debts whereas its outstanding debt is estimated at Ksh6 billion ($600 million), partly expected to be cleared in a rights issue. 
The company's share price had slid to Ksh2.10 ($0.02)by close of Thursday from Ksh3.20 ($0.03) in January. Kenya
